questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath over the past 3 months. He has been unable to climb the 3 flights of stairs to his apartment. Six years ago, he was diagnosed with HIV. He is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy, but he says that he often misses doses. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6° F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 160/70 mm Hg. There is a grade 4/6 holodiastolic murmur heard best at the right sternal border. The pupils are 4 mm, round, and not reactive to light. When a pen tip is advanced closer to the face, the pupils constrict. Extraocular movements are intact. When asked to stand, hold his arms in front of him, and close his eyes, he loses his balance and takes a step backward. An x-ray of the chest shows widening of the mediastinum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fibrillin gene mutation testing would be used to diagnose Marfan syndrome, which typically manifests with tall stature, joint hypermobility, and musculoskeletal abnormalities (e.g., pectus excavatum). While Marfan syndrome increases the risk of aortic aneurysm, which this patient most likely has, it would not cause fever or this patient's neurologic abnormalities. Moreover, there is no other evidence of Marfan syndrome on physical examination of this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Antinuclear antibody testing is a first-line screening test for many rheumatological diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which can cause fever and, rarely, thoracic aortic aneurysms. Moreover, SLE can cause a broad range of neuropsychiatric abnormalities, including peripheral neuropathy (which could cause a positive Romberg test). However, common neurologic symptoms of SLE include headache, seizure, delirium, and stroke, none of which are present in this patient. Additionally, the patient does not have a history of lupus, and no other clinical features of SLE (e.g., cutaneous lesions, polyarthralgia, malar rash) are present.

C) INCORRECT:

Antistreptolysin O is the first-line test for recent S. pyogenes infection, which can result in rheumatic fever (RF) and subsequent rheumatic heart disease. RF would explain this patient's heart failure, murmur, and fever. However, this patient has neither a history of RF, nor evidence of acute RF (i.e., positive Jones criteria). Additionally, RF may cause chorea in acute illness, but it would not explain this patient's positive Romberg test and pupillary findings. Finally, RF would not explain his widened mediastinum on x-ray.

D) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are indicated to diagnose bacteremia/fungemia, which could cause fever, infective endocarditis (IE) and/or mycotic aneurysm, and consequent heart murmur and heart failure. This patient is at increased risk for IE given his HIV infection. Although vegetations from IE can embolize and cause end-organ infarction such as stroke, neither Argyll Robertson pupils nor a positive Romberg test (which indicates involvement of the dorsal columns and/or peripheral neuropathy) are associated with stroke.

E) INCORRECT:

The frataxin level can be used to confirm Friedreich ataxia (FA), although the disease is usually diagnosed clinically. While patients with FA often develop heart failure, it is due to hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Based on the murmur (holodiastolic, best heard at the right sternal border) and the x-ray findings (showing mediastinal widening), this patient's heart failure is most likely due to thoracic aortic aneurysm with resulting aortic regurgitation. FA can manifest with sensory ataxia (and a positive Romberg test) and can lead to optic atrophy (presenting with loss of vision), but it would not explain this patient's fever or pupillary abnormality. Moreover, this patient lacks other features of FA (e.g., foot deformity, scoliosis).

F) CORRECT:

Treponemal tests (TTs), such as the fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) and the treponema pallidum particle agglutination test (TPPA), are used in the diagnosis of syphilis. Diagnosis is confirmed using a serial testing strategy. In the standard testing algorithm, a nontreponemal test (NTT), such as VDRL or plasma reagin test, is performed first. If the result is positive or equivocal, a TT is performed. In the reverse testing algorithm, a TT is performed first, followed by an NTT test. A positive result for both tests strongly supports the diagnosis of syphilis. This patient likely has tertiary syphilis as he shows signs of both neurosyphilis (positive Romberg test suggesting tabes dorsalis, Argyll Robertson pupil) and cardiac syphilis (ascending aortic aneurysm with consequent heart failure). Since the advent of antibiotics, neurosyphilis has become much less common. Patients with HIV (especially untreated) are at greatest risk of the disease. Tertiary syphilis usually occurs decades after infection with Treponema pallidum, but immunocompromised patients (e.g., due to HIV) may develop symptoms more rapidly. First-line treatment for neurosyphilis is IV penicillin G for 10–14 days.
Image Description:

FTA-ABS: fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption
NTT: nontreponemal test
RPR: rapid plasma reagin
TPPA: treponema pallidum particle agglutination
TT: treponemal test
VDRL: venereal disease research laboratory
questions.hint: Pupils that accommodate but are not reactive to light are called Argyll Robertson pupils.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever and generalized fatigue. Yesterday, he developed a rash all over his body. Two months ago, he had a painless lesion on his penis that resolved a few weeks later without treatment. He has asthma. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler. He is currently sexually active with 3 different partners. He uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. He has a diffuse maculopapular rash involving the trunk, extremities, palms, and soles. An HIV test is negative. Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) and fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) are positive. The patient receives a dose of intramuscular benzathine penicillin G. Two hours later, he reports headache, myalgias, and chills. His temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 98/67 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is indicated as an alternative treatment option for syphilis. However, this patient currently requires treatment for a complication he developed following therapy of the infection.

B) CORRECT:

NSAIDs such as ibuprofen are recommended for the treatment of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR). After administration of antibiotic treatment (usually in the early phases of the secondary stage of syphilis), the release of bacterial endotoxins and pyrogens can elicit a systemic reaction consisting of flu-like symptoms (fever, chills, headache, myalgia), tachypnea, hypotension, and tachycardia. JHR is a common complication of treatment of spirochetal infections (e.g., borreliosis, leptospirosis, syphilis) and is usually self-limiting within 12–24 hours.

C) INCORRECT:

Epinephrine is commonly used to treat anaphylactic reactions. While these may occur following medical treatment (e.g., with antibiotics) and may manifest with skin lesions, they are typically urticarial and not maculopapular. Since fever and myalgias are not caused by anaphylaxis and further typical symptoms (e.g., erythema, angioedema, dyspnea) are absent in this patient, the diagnosis is unlikely and treatment with epinephrine is not necessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Methylprednisolone is a steroidal antiinflammatory drug. Although it is effective in reducing inflammation in several conditions (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, allergies, asthma), it is not indicated for the treatment of Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction.

E) INCORRECT:

Phenylephrine is most commonly used as a decongestant, but can also be indicated as a vasopressor to treat hypotension (e.g., secondary to shock). While this patient experienced a drop in blood pressure, treatment for hypotension should be considered if blood pressure drops below 90/60 mm Hg and is therefore not required in this patient.
questions.hint: The patient has signs of secondary syphilis (generalized maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles), a few weeks after primary infection (painless penile lesion). A positive FTA-ABS test confirms the diagnosis. A common complication of treatment is the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for a rash that began 3 days ago. She has low-grade fever and muscle aches. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She has had 5 male sexual partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6° F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 126/89 mm Hg. Examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash that includes the palms and soles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A venereal disease research laboratory (VDRL) test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nontreponemal tests, such as the VDRL and the rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test, are sensitive but not specific for syphilis infection. This patient has symptoms consistent with syphilis and has already tested positive on a nontreponemal test; therefore, a positive treponemal test is required to confirm the diagnosis. Nontreponemal tests are performed to screen for infection, evaluate disease activity, and monitor response to treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Although bacterial cultures are used to detect a wide variety of pathogens, they cannot be used in the diagnosis of syphilis. Treponema are obligate intracellular organisms that can only survive in mammalian cells and cannot be cultured in the laboratory.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous penicillin is the treatment of choice for neurosyphilis. However, this patient does not present with any symptoms suggestive of neurosyphilis (e.g., tabes dorsalis, Argyll Robertson pupil). Furthermore, treatment should not be initiated until diagnosis has been confirmed since the VDRL test yields many false-positive results due to cross-reacting antibodies in patients with viral infections, rheumatic fever, lupus, or leprosy.

D) INCORRECT:

Dark-field microscopy is capable of directly visualizing Treponema pallidum and is one of two definitive tests for detecting primary and secondary syphilis (PCR is the other), although it has been replaced in many settings by serological testing. It requires a specimen that is taken from a skin lesion that contains high amounts of treponemes and only few blood cells (e.g., chancre, condyloma). However, this patient does not present with a chancre (primary syphilis) or condylomata lata (secondary syphilis).

E) INCORRECT:

A single dose of intramuscular penicillin is the treatment of choice for primary, secondary, and early latent syphilis infection. Although this patient most likely has secondary syphilis, treatment should not be initiated until the diagnosis has been confirmed since the VDRL test yields many false-positive results due to cross-reacting antibodies in patients with viral infections, rheumatic fever, lupus, or leprosy.

F) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline, a tetracycline, may be used to treat rickettsial and chlamydial infections. Doxycycline is also a treatment option for patients with syphilis who are allergic to penicillin. Although this patient most likely has secondary syphilis, treatment should not be initiated until the diagnosis has been confirmed since the venereal disease research laboratory VDRL test often yields false-positive results due to cross-reacting antibodies in patients with viral infections, rheumatic fever, lupus, or leprosy.

G) CORRECT:

Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) and Treponema pallidum particle agglutination (TPPA) assay are treponemal tests (TTs). The diagnosis of syphilis is confirmed using a serial testing strategy. In the standard testing algorithm, an NTT (e.g., VDRL, plasma reagin test) is performed first. If the result is positive or equivocal, a TT is performed. In the reverse testing algorithm, a TT is performed first, followed by an NTT test. A positive result for both tests strongly supports the diagnosis of syphilis. FTA-ABS tests become positive 2–3 weeks after infection and have a very high positive predictive value. Because treponemal tests usually remain positive regardless of treatment or disease activity, a positive FTA-ABS indicates either active syphilis infection or persistent antibodies from a prior infection.
questions.hint: Low-grade fever, myalgias, and a diffuse maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles are features of secondary syphilis. To confirm the diagnosis of syphilis, a positive nontreponemal test (NTT), such as VDRL, must be followed by a more specific test.

questions.text: A 27-year old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of a generalized rash. Over the past month, she has also had mild fever, headache, and myalgias. She has no personal history of serious illness. She smokes 1 pack of cigarettes a day and binge drinks on the weekends. She uses occasional cocaine, but denies other illicit drug use. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a widespread, symmetric, reddish-brown papular rash involving the trunk, upper extremities, and palms. There is generalized, nontender lymphadenopathy. Skin examination further shows patchy areas of hair loss on her scalp and multiple flat, broad-based, wartlike papules around her genitalia and anus. Rapid plasma reagin and fluorescent treponemal antibody test are both positive. In addition to starting treatment, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: NAAT for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhea

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is recommended in the diagnostic workup of suspected neurosyphilis (tertiary syphilis). This patient has symptoms of secondary syphilis but does not have any symptoms to suggest CNS involvement (e.g. dementia, Argyll Robertson pupils, tabes dorsalis).

B) INCORRECT:

The organism responsible for syphilis infection, Treponema pallidum, cannot be cultured in the laboratory. Diagnosis of syphilis infection is based on direct visualization of the spirochete in active lesions (in the case of primary syphilis), or based on serologic testing (in the case of advanced syphilis). This patient's serologic tests already confirm a diagnosis of syphilis and she does not have any other indication for blood culture testing at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Dark-field microscopy can detect spirochetes from active lesions (e.g. chancres) and can be used to diagnose syphilis. However, the combination of typical clinical features of syphilis and positive rapid plasma reagin and fluorescent treponemal antibody test is sufficient to diagnose syphilis, making dark-field microscopy unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

HIV-1/HIV-2 differentiation immunoassay is a confirmatory test used to diagnose HIV in patients with a positive HIV screening test (e.g., HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay). Although HIV screening is indicated in patients who are diagnosed with syphilis, the confirmatory test is only recommended for patients who have a positive screening test.

E) INCORRECT:

CT angiography of the chest could be used if vascular complications of tertiary syphilis (e.g. aortic aneurysm, aortitis, and aortic root dilation) were expected. However, this patient's fever, rash, and myalgias are hallmarks of secondary syphilis. She does not have any clinical findings to suggest tertiary syphilis at this time.

F) CORRECT:

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is sensitive and specific for diagnosing gonorrhea and chlamydia, the most common sexually transmitted infections. The presence of syphilis in this patient puts her at high risk of infection with other STIs (gonorrhea, chlamydia, HIV), and screening is therefore indicated. HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay is the first-line screening test to detect HIV infection.
questions.hint: A disseminated rash, generalized nontender lymphadenopathy, condylomata lata, patchy alopecia, and constitutional symptoms (fever, myalgia, headache) in combination with a positive rapid plasma reagin test (RPR test) and treponemal antibody test are diagnostic of secondary syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection (STI).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 10 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for her initial prenatal visit. She has no history of serious illness but reports that she is allergic to penicillin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation, and cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows an intrauterine pregnancy with no abnormalities. The fetal heart rate is 174/min. Routine prenatal laboratory tests are drawn. A rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test and a fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) test are positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer therapeutic dose of intramuscular penicillin G

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is a recommended treatment for syphilis in nonpregnant individuals with confirmed allergy to penicillin. However, administration of oral doxycycline (as a prophylactic measure) in pregnant women is contraindicated because tetracycline intake may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) in the offspring.

B) INCORRECT:

Penicillin G is the only agent proven to be safe and efficient for treating syphilis in pregnant women. However, the patient reports having had an allergic reaction to penicillin in the past. Therefore, before initiating therapy it should first be determined whether the patient can tolerate treatment with penicillin.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is a recommended treatment for syphilis in nonpregnant individuals with confirmed allergy to penicillin. There is limited data on its efficacy in pregnant women and its use in this group is not recommended for the treatment of syphilis. Additionally, cephalosporins should be used with caution in patients with penicillin allergies, as cross-reactions can occur and lead to severe hypersensitivity reactions.

D) CORRECT:

There are no proven alternatives to penicillin for the safe and effective treatment of syphilis in pregnant women. Therefore, desensitization to penicillin should be performed in all patients with penicillin allergies who are diagnosed with syphilis during pregnancy. The process of desensitization can be safely performed during pregnancy and does not adversely affect the pregnancy outcome. In conditions for which there are no acceptable alternate drugs, desensitization allows the drug of choice to be used and the complications associated with untreated infection to be avoided (in this case, transplacental infection of the fetus).

Penicillin allergies are reported in up to 10% of patients. However, reactions are not always due to hypersensitivity, and severe allergic reactions to penicillin are rare; approx. 85–90% of patients with a reported allergy will tolerate penicillin. An allergy evaluation should be conducted in patients with any history suggesting an allergy. It should include an epicutaneous (prick) test and, if the epicutaneous test is negative, an intradermal test. However, in patients with conditions that can only be treated with penicillin, a possible history of an allergic reaction qualifies the patient for desensitization even if allergy evaluation is not possible or if it delays the required treatment. Desensitization should be initiated (regardless of the allergen test report) because allergen tests are known to have poor sensitivity, and the risk of anaphylaxis is too great to rely on a single allergen test report.

E) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin can be used as a second-line drug in the treatment of syphilis in nonpregnant individuals with confirmed allergy to penicillin. However, the antibiotic does not freely cross the placental barrier, so the fetus will not be effectively treated. It is therefore not recommended for the treatment of syphilis during pregnancy.

F) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is inappropriate in this patient with confirmed syphilis (i.e., positive screening test and confirmatory test). Untreated syphilis infection puts both the mother and the child at risk of serious complications, including congenital syphilis, cardiovascular syphilis, and neurosyphilis.

G) INCORRECT:

An oral penicillin graded challenge test would be the appropriate next step in a patient with a negative penicillin skin test, which suggests the patient may not have an allergy to penicillin. This patient has a history of allergy to penicillin and, considering that the hypersensitivity has not been confirmed by allergen testing, it is prudent not to make assumptions about the patient's tolerance to the drug. In this patient, beginning with a graded penicillin challenge would be very dangerous, as it could result in anaphylaxis.
questions.hint: The treatment of choice for syphilis in pregnant patients is the same as for nonpregnant patients.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician 1 week after noticing a lesion on his penis. There is no history of itching or pain associated with the lesion. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Five weeks ago, he returned from a trip to the Caribbean with some of his football teammates. He has recently started an intense exercise program. He takes no medications. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple enlarged, nontender lymph nodes in the inguinal area bilaterally. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trichophyton rubrum is a common cause of tinea cruris, which manifests with pruritus and scaly erythema of the groin and adjacent skin that may worsen with exercise rather than the genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy seen in this patient.
Image Description:

There is a sharply demarcated, light gray lesion with a raised border and scaling around the pubic area and upper thighs.

These findings are consistent with tinea cruris.

B) INCORRECT:

While a sexually transmitted disease such as infection with Mycoplasma genitalium is not unlikely in a sexually active young man, symptomatic disease in a male patient would manifest with symptoms of urethritis (e.g., dysuria, urethral discharge) rather than the genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus infection commonly results in condyloma acuminata (anogenital warts). Patients present with multiple painless, cauliflower-like lesions on the penis and/or perineal region rather than the genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy seen here.
Image Description:

Multiple exophytic, cauliflower-like, confluent, skin-colored papules are visible in the perianal region.

D) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection that can manifest with a genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, both the genital ulcer and the lymph nodes will be severely painful, unlike the painless genital ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy seen here.
Image Description:

There is massive bilateral swelling of inguinal lymph nodes. The skin above the lymph nodes is livid. The causative agent is Haemophilus ducreyi.

E) CORRECT:

Treponema pallidum causes the sexually transmitted infection syphilis. In the earliest stage of syphilis (primary syphilis), patients present with a painless papule that evolves into an ulcer with a smooth base and indurated border (chancre) at the site of inoculation, as seen here. Painless, nonsuppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy occurs within a week of the chancre's appearance. If left untreated, the disease progresses after a period of 8–12 weeks to secondary syphilis with generalized nontender lymphadenopathy, polymorphic rash, fever, condylomata lata, and/or patchy alopecia. Finally, tertiary syphilis can cause cardiovascular manifestations (e.g., ascending aortic aneurysm) and neurosyphilis.

The presence of characteristic clinical features and positive serology raises suspicion for syphilis. Dark-field microscopy or PCR showing Treponema pallidum in exudate from the chancre confirms the diagnosis. Additionally, the patient should be offered HIV testing and screening for other sexually transmitted infections, as his syphilis infection is indicative of high-risk sexual behavior. Treatment of primary syphilis consists of a single intramuscular injection of penicillin G.

F) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus type 2 is a common cause of genital herpes, which can manifest with genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy. However, patients typically have multiple flat, painful erosions on an erythematous base, unlike the single painless ulcer with raised, non-inflamed margins seen here. Lymphadenopathy is usually tender, and constitutional symptoms such as fever and headache would also be expected.
Image Description:

Penile shaft and glans

Two ulcerated blisters with erythematous margins are visible proximal to the corona of the glans.

G) INCORRECT:

Serotypes L1, L2, and L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum (LV), a sexually transmitted disease that can cause painless genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy. LV is more common in subtropical and tropical countries, such as the Caribbean, putting this patient at increased risk. However, the ulcer is usually small and shallow and disappears by the time lymphadenopathy is apparent. Furthermore, lymphadenopathy would be quite painful, unlike the painless inguinal lymph nodes seen here. Also, patients frequently have systemic symptoms such as fever, chills, and myalgia.
Image Description:

A small, shallow ulcer is visible on the shaft of the penis (arrow).

This lesion is suggestive of early LGV caused by Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

H) INCORRECT:

While a sexually transmitted disease such as infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not unlikely in a sexually active young man, gonorrhea in a male patient would manifest with symptoms of urethritis (e.g., dysuria, purulent urethral discharge) rather than the genital ulcer and inguinal lymphadenopathy seen here.

I) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted infection that is endemic in tropical and subtropical countries, such as the Caribbean. Patients may present with a painless genital ulcer, but the ulcer has a red, beefy appearance (due to the vascular nature of the lesion) and typically does not cause regional lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: The lesion will evolve into an ulcer and spontaneously resolve if left untreated. However, the infection will manifest again after approximately 8 weeks with a diffuse, polymorphic, copper-colored rash involving the palms and soles.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of low-grade fever, muscle aches, and a rash. She has had 4 male sexual partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. Examination shows a diffuse maculopapular rash that includes the palms and soles. The remainder of the skin examination shows no abnormalities. There are no lesions in the oral or genital mucosa. Testing for nonspecific anticardiolipin antibodies is positive. An antinuclear antibody test is negative. It is most appropriate for the physician to order which of the following tests at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum C3 and/or C4 levels are decreased in patients with active systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and complement levels are used to monitor for disease activity. A low-grade fever, muscle aches, a positive anticardiolipin test, and a rash in a young woman raise concerns for SLE. However, a negative antinuclear antibody test (ANA) makes SLE unlikely. A maculopapular rash that involves the palms and soles in a patient with high-risk sexual behavior is more suggestive of syphilis, in which serum complement levels typically remain normal.

B) INCORRECT:

Although bacterial cultures are used to detect a wide variety of pathogens, they cannot be used in the diagnosis of syphilis. Treponema are obligate intracellular organisms that can only survive in mammalian cells and cannot be cultured in the laboratory.

C) INCORRECT:

Flow cytometry is used for the workup of hematologic diseases (e.g., leukemia, paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria) and immunodeficiencies (e.g., quantification of CD4+ T cells in patients with confirmed HIV infection). Screening for HIV infection using a combination HIV antibody with HIV antigen test should be performed in patients with confirmed syphilis but flow cytometry is not used in the workup of syphilis.

D) INCORRECT:

Darkfield microscopy using a wet mount from certain mucocutaneous lesions can directly visualize the Treponema pallidum spirochete and confirm syphilis. However, T. pallidum is only present in infectious syphilitic lesions such as the chancre of primary syphilis and condylomata lata of secondary syphilis. Condylomata lata are broad-based, wart-like lesions typically present in the anogenital folds, oral mucosa, and intertriginous areas. The polymorphic disseminated rash of secondary syphilis is the result of an immunologic reaction and a wet mount from this rash would not contain T. pallidum.

E) CORRECT:

The fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test (FTA-ABS) is a treponemal test (TT). The diagnosis of syphilis is confirmed using a serial testing strategy. In the standard testing algorithm, an NTT (e.g., VDRL, plasma reagin test) is performed first. If the result is positive or equivocal, a TT is performed. In the reverse testing algorithm, a TT is performed first, followed by an NTT test. A positive result for both tests strongly supports the diagnosis of syphilis. Because treponemal tests usually remain positive regardless of treatment or disease activity, a positive FTA-ABS indicates either active syphilis infection or persistent antibodies from a prior infection.
Image Description:

FTA-ABS: fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption
NTT: nontreponemal test
RPR: rapid plasma reagin
TPPA: treponema pallidum particle agglutination
TT: treponemal test
VDRL: venereal disease research laboratory
questions.hint: The presence of nonspecific anticardiolipin antibodies is assessed with the Venereal Disease Research Laboratory test (VDRL), which is a nontreponemal test (NTT). In addition to the positive VDRL, this patient has a low-grade fever, myalgias, and a diffuse maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles, all of which suggest secondary syphilis.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of sharp, shooting pain in both legs. Twenty years ago, he had a painless ulcer on his penis that resolved without treatment. He has no history of serious illness. Examination shows small pupils that constrict with accommodation but do not react to light. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the distal lower extremities. Patellar reflexes are absent bilaterally. His gait is unsteady and broad-based. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Development of atrioventricular block can be caused by various etiologies (e.g., infection, cardiomyopathy, ischemia); the most common infectious causes include Lyme disease and infective endocarditis (IE). This patient's syphilis infection would not increase his risk of developing atrioventricular block.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitral valve regurgitation is a potential complication of rheumatic fever (RF) or rheumatic heart disease (due to untreated RF). RF can also manifest with neurological sequelae (e.g., Sydenham chorea); however, paresthesia and pupillary involvement would not be expected. This patient's syphilis infection would not increase his risk of developing mitral valve regurgitation.

C) INCORRECT:

Penile squamous cell carcinoma is associated with infection from high-risk strains of human papillomavirus (i.e., HPV-16, HPV-18). Anogenital lesions caused by HPV are usually raised, cauliflower-like, and exophytic, rather than the painless ulcers reported by this patient. This patient's syphilis infection would not increase his risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Cerebral artery septic embolism is almost exclusively seen in left-sided infective endocarditis, especially with Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus bovis infection, and can lead to the development of mycotic aneurysm. This patient has evidence of syphilis infection, which is not known to cause embolization.

E) INCORRECT:

Inflammatory polyarthritis can occur in patients with disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) or reactive arthritis, but not syphilis infection. While synovitis can develop in patients with syphilis, it is more typically seen in secondary syphilis, and would classically manifest within 10 weeks of primary infection; this patient's infection has been present for much longer.

F) CORRECT:

In addition to tabes dorsalis and Argyll Robertson pupil, patients with tertiary syphilis are at risk of developing thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA) from aortitis. Treponemal-mediated destruction of the vasa vasorum classically affects the ascending aorta and can also lead to aortic root dilatation and aortic regurgitation. These cardiovascular complications are late manifestations of syphilis, and typically only occur after 15 years of untreated infection.
questions.hint: This patient has evidence of tabes dorsalis (ataxia, lower extremity pain, impaired sensation in the lower extremities) and Argyll Robertson pupil (impaired pupillary constriction), suggesting tertiary syphilis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male comes to the physician because of a 1-week-history of a painless ulceration on his penis. The patient is sexually active with multiple partners and does not use barrier protection. Physical examination shows a shallow, firm ulcer with a smooth base along the shaft of the penis and nontender bilateral inguinal adenopathy. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although blood cultures are effective diagnostic methods in several infectious diseases, T. pallidum cannot be cultured.

B) INCORRECT:

A Tzanck test can be used to diagnose skin lesions resulting from herpes virus infections such as HSV1, varicella zoster, or cytomegalovirus infection. A Tzanck smear has no role in the early diagnosis of syphilis and would be negative in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Although swab cultures are effective diagnostic methods in several infectious diseases, T. pallidum cannot be cultured.

D) INCORRECT:

PCR can be used to directly detect a pathogen by specifically amplifying its DNA or RNA. Although PCR from urine samples is used to diagnose several sexually transmitted diseases (e.g., gonorrhea, Chlamydia trachomatis infection), a PCR for syphilis requires samples from the ulcer itself. Therefore, a solitary PCR from this patient's urine would not be helpful in confirming the diagnosis, and likely yield a negative result.

E) CORRECT:

Darkfield microscopy is a diagnostic method that allows direct visualization of T. pallidum from the lesion's serous exudate. This confirms the diagnosis without the use of a screening serologic test, which have a high false-negative rate in early primary syphilis.

F) INCORRECT:

Serologic screening tests for syphilis include treponemal tests, which detect antibodies against antigens from T. pallidum (e.g., fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption (FTA-ABS) test), and non-treponemal tests, which detect antibodies against cellular damage caused by the bacteria (e.g., rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test). Nontreponemal tests are nonspecific and often used as a first screen. Treponemal tests are then used if the nontreponemal tests yield positive or equivocal results. However, in early primary syphilis, as seen in this patient, all serologic tests have a high false-negative rate and are therefore not suitable for early confirmation of the diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's solitary, nontender, ulcerated lesion with indurated borders (chancre) located on the penis indicates early primary syphilis, which is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochetal organism.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with well-controlled HIV on antiretroviral therapy comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of a painless lesion on her right calf. Many years ago, she had a maculopapular rash over her trunk, palms, and soles that resolved spontaneously. Physical examination shows a 4-cm firm, nontender, indurated ulcer with a moist, dark base and rolled edges. There is a similar lesion at the anus. Results of rapid plasma reagin testing are positive. Which of the following findings is most likely on microscopic examination of these lesions?

choices.text: Spindle-shaped cells with leukocyte infiltrate and angiogenesis
Epidermal hyperplasia with dermal lymphocytic infiltrate
Lichenoid hyperplasia with superficial neutrophilic infiltrate
Ulcerated epidermis with plasma cell infiltrate
Necrotic area surrounded by fibroblast and macrophage infiltrate

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A biopsy showing spindle-shaped cells, leukocyte infiltration, and angiogenesis is consistent with Kaposi sarcoma, for which HIV is a risk factor. Cutaneous findings of Kaposi sarcoma include darkly pigmented plaques and nodules that may ulcerate. However, this patient's HIV is well controlled on retroviral therapy (reducing her chance of developing Kaposi sarcoma) and her history and positive rapid plasma reagin test are more consistent with tertiary syphilis.

B) INCORRECT:

A biopsy showing epidermal hyperplasia with lymphocytic infiltrates can be seen in condylomata lata, a skin lesion characteristic of secondary syphilis. Macroscopically, these lesions appear as broad-based, wart-like papular erosions. Although this patient has a remote history suggesting secondary syphilis, her current skin findings are more consistent with those seen in tertiary syphilis.

C) INCORRECT:

A biopsy showing lichenoid hyperplasia with superficial neutrophilic infiltrates would be seen in secondary syphilis, which manifests macroscopically as a disseminated, maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles. Patients with secondary syphilis may also present with condylomata lata. Although this patient has a remote history suggesting secondary syphilis, her current skin findings are more consistent with those seen in tertiary syphilis.

D) INCORRECT:

A biopsy showing ulcerated epidermis with plasma cell infiltration should raise concern for chancre, a skin lesion characteristic of primary syphilis. These lesions are typically painless, solitary, and localized to the genital region. Although this patient has a painless lesion near the anus, she also has a second lesion on her leg, and a history that should raise suspicion for secondary syphilis (polymorphic rash over palms and soles). This makes chancre, a manifestation of primary syphilis infection, an unlikely diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Gummas are granulomatous skin lesions characteristic of tertiary syphilis. A biopsy of a gumma would most likely show a central area of necrosis (due to obliterating endarteritis, which causes ischemia of the lesion's center) surrounded by an inflammatory cellular infiltrate (due to a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction to Treponemal spirochetes). Gummas may form on the skin, CNS (neurosyphilis), bones, and/or internal organs. They appear in advanced Treponemal pallidum infections and are more common in patients with HIV infection.
questions.hint: This patient's current skin lesions are most likely gummas, a sign of tertiary syphilis. Her remote history of rash is suggestive of secondary syphilis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a genital lesion that she first noticed 3 days ago. There is no pain or pruritus and the patient has had no vaginal discharge. Six months ago, she had a lower urinary tract infection that was treated with oral nitrofurantoin. She is sexually active with a new male partner, whom she met 2 weeks ago. She has an intrauterine device and uses condoms consistently. She has no history of serious illness or allergies and takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes. She drinks one to two alcoholic beverages on weekends. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 122/65 mm Hg. A photograph of the vulva is shown. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral azithromycin is the preferred treatment for granuloma inguinale, which can manifest with painless genital ulcers. However, granuloma inguinale ulcers have rolled granulomatous borders, continuously enlarge, bleed easily, and are described as “beefy-red.” In addition, the causal pathogen is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries; granuloma inguinale is uncommon in the US.
Image Description:

Coronal sulcus on an adult penis with three solitary, round, ulcerating lesions. This finding indicates granuloma inguinale, a sexually transmitted bacterial disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. Granuloma inguinale is endemic to tropical and subtropical countries.

B) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice for chancroid, which can manifest with well-circumscribed genital ulcers. However, patients usually develop painful, erythematous ulcers with a necrotic base and purulent exudate, rather than a single painless ulcer with indurated borders. Additionally, chancroid is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy and abscess formation, which is not seen here.
Image Description:

A small, red ulcer can be seen on the posterior vaginal wall (arrow). The pathogen that causes chancroid is Haemophilus ducreyi.

C) CORRECT:

Although consistent use of barrier contraception significantly lowers the risk of infection with syphilis, it can still be transmitted via skin-to-skin contact with an active lesion (e.g., base of the penis, oral cavity). A single dose of intramuscular penicillin G is the first-line treatment for primary, secondary, and early latent syphilis. Doxycycline or ceftriaxone can be administered to patients who are allergic to penicillin. Patients should also be counseled on the risk of a Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction, which is an acute, self-limiting (< 1 day), systemic reaction to bacterial endotoxins and pyrogens that are released after the initiation of antibiotic therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is the preferred treatment for lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which can manifest with painless genital ulcers during the primary phase of infection. However, most affected individuals present with multiple small, herpetiform lesions, rather than a single well-circumscribed ulcer with indurated borders. In addition, LGV is often accompanied by painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, which is not seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is the preferred treatment for herpes simplex virus infection, which can manifest with genital lesions. However, affected individuals typically present with grouped painful vesicles on an erythematous base, rather than a single painless ulcer with indurated borders.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.
questions.hint: A painless, well-circumscribed, ulcerative lesion with indurated borders in a patient with a new sexual partner should raise concern for a chancre.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of nonpainful swelling of his neck. He is otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. He is sexually active with multiple female partners. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years, and he typically drinks two to three beers daily. He has received all scheduled immunizations until the age of 10 years but has not received any immunizations since then. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.7°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Examination of the oral cavity shows a nontender, 15-mm ulcer on the soft palate with raised, indurated borders and a shallow nonexudative base. The anterior cervical lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally but are not tender to palpation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 14.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6500/mm3, and platelet count is 170,000/mm3. Fine-needle aspiration cytology of the cervical lymph node shows reactive follicular hyperplasia. Which of the following measures would most likely have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Completing the immunization schedule (via catch-up immunization) protects against vaccine-preventable diseases such as diphtheria and HPV infection. Diphtheria manifests acutely with sore throat, malaise, fever, pseudomembranous pharyngitis, and painful lymphadenopathy. Oral HPV infection manifests with warts or oropharyngeal squamous cell cancer (SCC). Oropharyngeal SCC can result in a nontender ulcerative lesion and painless cervical lymphadenopathy, but there is no evidence of a malignancy on this patient's lymph node biopsy. There is currently no immunization available against this patient's infection.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is at increased risk of contracting a sexually transmitted infection (STI) because he has multiple partners. His nontender oral ulcer with raised, indurated borders (chancre) and concomitant nontender lymphadenopathy (due to reactive follicular hyperplasia) is consistent with primary syphilis. The chancre is usually solitary, and develops at the site of inoculation after about 3 weeks. The chancre resolves without scarring after 3–6 weeks regardless of treatment. While primary syphilitic lesions most often occur in the genital region, about 5–10% of cases of primary syphilis are extragenital. Typical localizations are the oral cavity, hands and fingers, or the anus and perianal region, which reflect sexual practices, but chancres can occur wherever the skin has been in contact with Treponema pallidum from infectious sores. The use of a condom during vaginal or anal sex, and a dental dam during oral sex, can protect an individual against STIs by preventing contact with body fluids or an infectious lesion.

C) INCORRECT:

Smoking is one of the most important risk factors for head and neck cancers, and a nontender, ulcerative lesion with concomitant nontender cervical lymphadenopathy is also consistent with malignancy. However, fine-needle aspiration cytology shows no signs of malignancy (e.g., keratin pearls in squamous cell carcinoma, the most common mucosal head and neck cancer); reactive follicular hyperplasia suggests another etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

Dietary restriction of gluten is used to prevent manifestations of celiac disease (CD), which is caused by a maladaptive immune response to this protein. CD can lead to oral lesions as a result of malabsorption and nutrient deficiency. However, the oral manifestations of CD are poor dentition, atrophic glossitis, recurrent aphthous stomatitis, and cheilitis. The appearance of this patient's oral ulcer, its painless nature, and the concomitant cervical lymphadenopathy are inconsistent with any of the oral manifestations of CD. Moreover, this patient does not have signs typically seen in CD, such as chronic diarrhea, recurrent abdominal pain, and signs of malabsorption such as weight loss, fatigue, or anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used in the treatment of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, which can cause oral ulceration and lymphadenopathy. However, HSV infection typically causes multiple, shallow ulcers with flat margins, and both the ulcerations and lymphadenopathy would be painful. Furthermore, herpes infections are prone to recurrence even with acyclovir therapy; previous acyclovir therapy would not have prevented a new episode. Acyclovir only decreases the duration and severity of an active episode and reduces viral shedding during the episode.
questions.hint: If this patient had a rapid plasma reagin test, it would likely be positive.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 28 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I have a bump on my anus.” 
History of Present Illness:


3-day history of a painless, solitary lump on his anus
no pruritus or bleeding 

Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
mother age 45 years, father age 55 years, brother age 16 years: alive with no chronic conditions
Psychosocial History:

smokes marijuana occasionally
binge drinking on weekends
sexually active with multiple male partners, uses condoms inconsistently
has not traveled in the past 9 months


Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
